statement.tex: %text Find the point on the line % \qquad\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2} \\ %text at a distance $\sqrt{5}$ units from the point $(1,2,3)$. %

step.context: %text What are the co-ordinates of a general point on the line $\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$? %
step.reason: \begin{align} &\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}=k\,\text{(say)} \\ &\dfrac{x+2}{3}=k\implies x=3k-2 \\ &\dfrac{y+1}{2}=k\implies y=2k-1 \\ &\dfrac{z-3}{2}=k\implies z=2k+3 \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, any point on the given line can be expressed as $(3k-2,2k-1,2k+3)$ where $k\in R$. %

step.context: %text For what value of $r$ does the distance between $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$ and $(1,2,3)$ equal $\sqrt{5}$. %
step.reason:
%text Distance between any two points $(x_1,y_1,z_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2, z_2)$ is, % \qquad\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2+(z_2-z_1)^2} \\
%text Therefore, if distance between $(1,2,3)$ and $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$ is $\sqrt{5}$ then, %
\begin{tabular}{rr} &(3k-2)^2+(2k-3)^2+(2k)^2=5 \\ \implies &17k^2-30k+13=0 \\ \implies &k=1,\dfrac{13}{17} \end{tabular} \\
%text The co-ordinates of the point for which the distance between the two points is $\sqrt{5}$ are, % \begin{tabular}{|l|c|} \hline \text{For }k=1 & (1, 1, 5) \\ \hline \text{For }k=\dfrac{13}{17} & \left(\frac{5}{17},\frac{9}{17},\frac{77}{17}\right) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
